lines.content: 3. Open a terminal and navigate to the folder containing `pesto.jar`.
4. Run the program using the command:
5. Start interacting with Pesto by entering commands.

public Event(String description, String from, String to) {
* The {@code Parser} class is responsible for interpreting and executing user commands.
* It processes user input and performs corresponding actions on the {@link TaskList}.
* Parses the user's command and executes the corresponding action.
* @param taskList The task list to perform operations on.
* @param ui      The UI handler for displaying messages.
* @param storage The storage handler for saving and loading tasks.
* @return {@code false} if the command is "bye" (to exit the application),
*         otherwise {@code true} to continue running the program.
public boolean parseCommand(String input, TaskList taskList, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
ui.showMessage("The description of a todo cannot be empty.");
ui.showMessage("The description of a deadline must contain '/by'.");
ui.showMessage("The description of an event must contain '/from' and '/to'.");
Task event = new Event(details[0].trim(), details[1].trim(), details[2].trim());
ui.showMessage("You need to specify a task number to delete.");
+ "\nNow you have " + taskList.getTasks().size() + " tasks in the list.");
ui.showMessage("Specify a task number to mark.");
ui.showMessage("Nice! I've marked this task as done:\n" + taskList.getTask(taskNumber));
ui.showMessage("Specify a task number to unmark.");
ui.showMessage("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:\n" + taskList.getTask(taskNumber));
ui.showMessage("Please provide a keyword to search for.");
StringBuilder result = new StringBuilder("Here are the matching tasks in your list:\n");
* The {@code Pesto} class represents the main entry point of the Pesto task management application.
* It initializes the necessary components such as the {@link Storage},
* to handle user input, manage tasks, and store data persistently.
* Initializes a new instance of the Pesto application.
* @param filePath The file path where tasks are stored and retrieved.
* Starts the Duke application, displaying a welcome message and continuously
* processing user input until the user exits.
* The main entry point of the application.
* Creates an instance of Pesto and starts the program.
* The {@code Storage} class handles loading and saving tasks to a file.
* It is responsible for persisting task data between program runs.
* Constructs a new {@code Storage} instance with the specified file path.
* @param filePath The file path where task data is stored.
* Loads tasks from the specified file and returns them as a list.
* If the file does not exist, an empty list is returned.
* @return A {@code List<Task>} containing tasks loaded from the file.
* Saves the provided list of tasks to a file.
* If the file or directories do not exist, they are created automatically.
* @param tasks The {@code List<Task>} of tasks to be saved.
* The {@code Task} class represents a general task in the Pesto task manager.
* It serves as a base class for specific task types such as {@link ToDo}, {@link Deadline}, and {@link Event}.
* Constructs a new {@code Task} with the given description.
* The task is initially marked as not done.
* @param description The description of the task.
* Marks the task as not done.
* Returns the description of the task.
* @return The task description as a {@code String}.
* Returns a formatted string representation of the task for saving to a file.
* @return The formatted string for file storage.
return (this instanceof ToDo ? "T" : this instanceof Deadline ? "D" : "E")
* Returns a string representation of the task for display in the task list.
* The {@code TaskList} class manages the list of tasks in the Pesto task manager.
* It provides methods for adding, deleting, marking, and searching for tasks.
* Constructs a new {@code TaskList} with an existing list of tasks.
* If the provided list is {@code null}, an empty list is initialized.
* @param tasks The list of tasks to initialize with.
this.tasks = tasks != null ? tasks : new ArrayList<>();
* Adds a new task to the list and displays a confirmation message.
* @param task The {@code Task} to be added.
ui.showMessage("Added: " + task + "\nNow you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Deletes a task from the list if the index is valid.
* @param index The index of the task to be deleted (zero-based).
* Marks a task as done or not done based on the given flag.
* @param index  The index of the task to be marked (zero-based).
* @param isDone {@code true} to mark the task as done, {@code false} to mark it as not done.
public void markTask(int index, boolean isDone) {
* Retrieves a task at a specific index.
* @param index The index of the task to retrieve (zero-based).
* @return The {@code Task} at the specified index, or {@code null} if the index is invalid.
* Prints all tasks in the list. If there are no tasks, a message is displayed.
ui.showMessage("No tasks found! Start your list today.");
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
* Searches for tasks that contain the given keyword in their description.
* @param keyword The keyword to search for (case-insensitive).
* @return A {@code List<Task>} containing all matching tasks.
* The {@code Ui} class handles all user interactions in the Pesto task manager.
* It is responsible for displaying messages, taking user input, and formatting output.
* Constructs a new {@code Ui} instance and initializes a {@code Scanner} for user input.
* Displays the welcome message when the application starts.
System.out.println(" What can I do for you?");
* Reads and returns user input from the command line.
* @return The user's input as a {@code String}.
* Displays the exit message when the user quits the application.
System.out.println(" Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Displays a formatted message with separators.
* Displays the number of tasks currently in the task list.
* @param taskCount The total number of tasks in the list.
System.out.println(" Now you have " + taskCount + " tasks in the list.");
